svcsubproc.title: Output Shaft and Rear Bearing Assemblies

step1.para: Secure the output shaft in a vise with the threaded end up ( Figure 258). For models so equipped, install the stepped washer on the shaft, large diameter step down (arrow), then install the splined spacer.

figure.caption: Figure 257. Install Stepped Washer on Shaft, Large Diameter Step Down

step1.para: For 14609 Models, install the spacer with the large diameter splines down ( Figure 259).

figure.caption: Figure 258. Install Spacer With Large Diameter Splines Down

para.emph: IMPORTANT: Mark any two adjacent teeth on low range gear and repeat the procedure for the two adjacent teeth directly opposite the first set marked ( Figure 260). A highly visible color of toolmaker's dye is recommended.

figure.caption: Figure 259. Mark Teeth on Low Range Gear

step1.para: If previously removed, install the snap ring in the low range gear of models so equipped ( inset, Figure 261). Install the gear on the output shaft, clutching teeth down and engaged with the splines of the spacer.

figure.caption: Figure 260. Install Snap Ring in Low Range Gear, and Install Gear on Output Shaft

step1.para: Install the washer on the shaft; 11609, 12609 Models flat side of washer facing up, 14609 Models flat side of washer facing down ( Figure 262).
Heat the front bearing cone and install on shaft against washer, bearing taper up ( Figure 263).

figure.caption: Figure 262. Heat and Install Front Bearing Cone on Shaft

note.para: Do not heat bearing above 275 degrees F (136 degrees C). If possible, use heat lamps as source.

step1.para: Install the bearing inner spacer on the output shaft ( Figure 264).

figure.caption: Figure 263. Install Bearing Inner Spacer on Output Shaft

step1.para: Place the front bearing cup in the auxiliary housing bore, taper to the inside ( Figure 265) and use a soft bar to start cup into the bore.

figure.caption: Figure 264. Place Front Bearing Cup in Auxiliary Housing Bore

step1.para: Place the bearing outer spacer against cup ( Figure 266). Use a soft bar or a flanged-end driver to move both parts evenly into the bore.

figure.caption: Figure 265. Place Bearing Outer Spacer Against Cup

step1.para: Place the rear bearing cup against the spacer ( Figure 267). Use a flanged-end driver to move all three parts evenly into the bore until the lip of the rear bearing cup seats on the auxiliary housing.

figure.caption: Figure 266. Place Rear Bearing Cup Against Spacer

step1.para: Install the auxiliary housing over the end of the output shaft assembly ( Figure 268). Heat the rear bearing cone and install on shaft, taper down and inside bearing cup.

figure.caption: Figure 267. Install Auxiliary Housing Over End of Output Shaft Assembly

note.para: Do not heat bearing above 275 degrees F (136 degrees C).

step1.para: If previously removed, install the oil seal in the rear bearing cover with a flanged driver ( inset, Figure 269). Seal should be installed so the spring is to the front of the transmission.

figure.caption: Figure 268. Install Oil Seal in Rear Bearing Cover With Spring to Front of Transmission

step1.para: Mount the assembly upright in vise and secure on flange of the auxiliary housing ( Figure 270). Position the new gasket on the cover mounting surface and install the rear bearing cover. Use the nylon collar and brass washer with bolt at the chamfered hole which intersects speedometer bore ( inset, Figure 270). Apply Loctite 242 to the bolt threads and tighten the bolts to 35 to 45 ft-lbs. (47 to 61 Nm) to secure the cover to the auxiliary housing.

figure.caption: Figure 269. Secure Assembly on Flange of Auxiliary Housing, and Use Nylon Collar and Brass Washer

note.para: Because the collar becomes distorted when compressed, DO NOT REUSE OLD NYLON COLLAR.
